content.content: Delegate Address: 0x070341aA5Ed571f0FB2c4a5641409B1A46b4961b Forum: @juanbug Discord: juanbug#9225 Email: [email protected] External Website: http://pennblockchain.com/ Delegation Contract: 0x7Ddb50A5b15AeA7e7cf9aC8E55a7F9fd9d05ecc6 Core Values  Broadcast Maker to not only Penn, but the greater University community Help Maker through its Layer-2 and cross network integrations Advise and support Maker with Treasury Management initiatives Educate and teach students about the Maker project, expanding its connections with University teams and provide opportunities for future collaborations  Delegate Statement Hello everyone! We’re Penn Blockchain (@PennBlockchain on twitter), a leading, completely student run blockchain organization from The University of Pennsylvania for both our undergraduate and graduate schools. The club currently has over 50 members and we’re expecting many more next semester! Penn Blockchain has committees covering Governance, Research, Education, Business Development, and Development/Web3. On the governance side of things, our team has different members leading governance initiatives for different protocols we have delegations for. Current Penn Blockchain delegations include Aave, Compound, Uniswap, DyDx, IndexCoop, etc. Each week, governance leads will share updates with the club about new proposals and we will all debate about what to do before voting with our wallet. Our internal voting process takes place on the weekends and is an equal weighted democratic process. Proposals that will expire before the weekend are debated on our internal messaging platforms with a majority vote being our overall end vote. Other governance initiatives involve:  Staying active within discussion forums Drafting new proposals when appropriate Staying up to date with protocols covered Discuss models and parameters with leading analysis companies like Gauntlet Communicating with internal team members Hosting speaker events with projects in conjunction with BD  We’d love to be your Maker delegate as many of us have been following Maker for years now. Our weekly discussions combine graduates with years of expertise in many jurisdictions with many bright minded undergrads eager to leave their impact and names in Web3. Members of our club are also actively working with the MakerDAO team internally on different projects, such as deploying a set amount of treasury assets in on chain initiatives. When delegating with us, rest assured your tokens are in the hands of one of the most hardworking and determined Blockchain clubs out there. It’s a vote of confidence in University Blockchain clubs and we greatly appreciate your support. Finally, delegation with us is an agreement on our end to continue to do our due diligence and uphold quality and consistent work. As always, thanks so much for your time and we truly appreciate your consideration. Possible Conflicts of Interest  Penn Blockchain takes part actively in the governance of other well known projects This proposal’s author (juanbugeth on twitter) is helping internally with MakerDAO with possible on chain strategies for increasing treasury and liquidity for DAI  I have read and agree to abide by the Delegate Code of Conduct. Waiver of liability By delegating to Penn Blockchain, you acknowledge and agree that Penn Blockchain will participate on a best efforts basis and will not be liable for any form of damages related to participation in the Maker Protocol, or MakerDAO.

content.content: Ratification Poll for Methodology and Review Process for Structured Finance Transactions (MIP67) - April 11, 2022 We voted YES: In consistency with our previous Real World Asset proposal decision, we believe creating this structured and more well defined process for reviewing structured finance transactions is a necessity. With taking on real world exposure, it’s important to understand and realize that some defaults and mishaps will happen. However, there’s a reason why companies in traditional finance take on risks as in the long run they will be profitable. This similar thought process is what we believe Maker should take on. content.content: Ratification Poll for Pairwyse Licensure (MIP66) - April 11, 2022. We voted NO: When diving deeper in this proposal, a few key points stood out to us. Firstly, the fee structure and cost for Maker come in very high. Additionally, we just didn’t see the value add that would arise from this situation. The vaults seem to be something that we could easily employ ourselves with no need for exorbitant fees from a third party. Additionally, a few members with legal background brought up the huge regulatory concerns regarding this decision. A fixed rate instrument, something closely monitored and oversaw by the SEC, could just complicate things further. Finally, when looking at the forums and community, we don’t see the necessary demand for this product, at least at the current time to warrant this implementation. This could be a proposal worth noting and revisiting months down the line.

Ratification Poll for Update Data Insights Core Unit Mandate (MIP39c2-SP31) - April 11, 2022 We voted ABSTAIN: This is much like our prior abstain vote, due to inexperience. We will be closely monitoring how these budget proposals pass and be better equipped for future decisions. Overall, just for some insight, many of us were a lot more leaning towards NO for this than our other abstains this week. This is because many see the budget increases as too steep of an increase. A few of the glaring concerns were 8-80k for operations and some pretty steep salary raises. That being said, we realize as more and more money enters the space to “steal” away good talent, we need to remain competitive in our pay. Nonetheless, we encourage all CUs to remain diligent in their non salary expenses.

EXECUTIVE VOTE: ## Offload TUSD and DAI Transfers - April 15, 2022 This proposal we voted for will offload the TUSD held in collateral. All accounts liquidated will not incur losses and the liquidation bonus will be 0%. 474,683 DAI will be transferred to the Growth Core Unit as stated in their active budget proposal, and 25,000 DAI will be transferred to the Ambassadors Program multi-sig.

Last thing we want is for white hackers to hate on Maker for being underpaid and not getting funds fast enough. (As ElPro pointed out in the forums) Whitelist Oasis.app on Multiple Oracles (MIP10c9-SP30) - April 18, 2022 We voted YES: We saw this as a great way to expand oracle price feed for Maker. Pretty simple play; good thing to note was the first year fees were waived and then we could discuss subsequent fees in a year. Community Greenlight Poll - sETH2 (Stakewise Staked ETH) - April 18, 2022 We voted YES: The forum post detailing this proposal was well written and reinforces our general opinion that the future of ETH will be more and more liquid staking derivatives. Stakewise’s proposal for this is in our eyes another great liquid staking option. Community Greenlight Poll - HVBANK (Huntingdon Valley Bank Loan Syndication Collateral) - April 18, 2022 We voted YES: After talking with different respective parties and learning more about the lengthy application and proposal, we believe the research and due diligence done by both RWAC and the Maker team is exemplary and well researched. Overall, this initiative is part of a larger initiative into Real World Assets, and is something we strongly support. We encourage everyone to check out the original proposal and dig through some of the nuances and details if you have time!

content.content: Extend Strategic Happiness Core Unit (SH-001) Budget Until May Governance Cycle - April 25, 2022 We voted YES: This is one of those wholesome things that we think is pretty crucial to Maker. Seeing this core unit first hand at Harvard Blockchain Conference was one of the reasons why we became first hand interested in Maker. Overall, having a light hearted fun core unit for Maker is something that we think is incredibly important. In a time where many young people are getting into crypto, a core unit for keeping things spruced up is something that we believe is well worth the budget. Add wstETH-B as a new Vault Type - April 25, 2022 We voted YES: 100% Yes. As we’ve said in the past, we’re a huge fan of introducing new collateral with liquid staking options. We are firm believers that the future will have more and more liquid staking options. Creating a new vault using wstETH-B as collateral is a very good start.

EXECUTIVE VOTE: Core Unit Budget Distributions - April 29, 2022 We thank the core units for all they do and hope the DAI for their budgets is sent out in a timely fashion. We urge all CUs to carefully spend all their budgets and save costs when possible. This next year will be test Maker’s dominance and we’re confident the CUs will continue their good work.

Community Greenlight Poll - IPCL (India Power Green Bonds) - May 2, 2022 We Voted YES: Much in line with our intuition for ATDC, these real world relationships are definitely something we believe we should explore in the future and if we want to scale in a reasonable speed in the future, all this groundwork is needed to do so. Community Greenlight Poll - ATDC (ATD Combustors) - May 2, 2022 We voted YES: ATDC offerings is a real world partnership with a SEC and FINRA regulated broker dealer. As said prior, these relationships are the groundwork of future growth and 100% things we should explore in the near term. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - May 2, 2022 We voted YES: We believe that although these lower stability fees are beneficial in the short term of Maker acquiring more TVL and offering less friction to the platform, we don’t see this as an end all be all. We encourage Maker to think of alternative ways to incentivize usage of vaults and hope there isn’t a “race to the bottom.” Investigate Implementation of a TrueFi D3M - May 2, 2022 We voted YES: This vote is one of both incredible optimism and excitement, as well as well deserved caution. We believe talks in the near to medium future of D3M and ways of having programmable loans given out is the way of the future. However, when the responsibility of issuing DAI falls on others, we have to be super careful about checks and balances placed in to hold each other accountable and also prioritize the security of the protocol.

EXECUTIVE VOTE: Recognized Delegate Payments, Lowering WBTC Stability Fees, and Onboarding wstETH-B - May 11, 2022 We voted YES: While obviously losing some revenue is never a positive thing, we believe that the accumulation of staked ETH in our pools will in the long run be advantageous as people realize the true power and benefit of such. As for the delegate payments, falls in line with the past. Ratification Poll for Monetalis Clydesdale, Liquid Bond Strategy & Execution (MIP65) - May 9, 2022 We voted YES: Of this MIP, we love the commitment to deliver all the surplus mack to the FAO on a quarterly basis. Additionally, for a long time now, we have needed to diversify the PSM from USDC and this is a great logical way to do so. Additionally, having professional bod managers looking over stuff from a RWA standpoint is very nice, and coupled with the fact that this will be one of the first RWA strategies to return on investment, this is one we are definitely interested in exploring. Ratification Poll for Monetalis Lusitano, UK Green Economy SME Wholesale Lending (MIP68) - May 9, 2022 We voted YES: First off, very interesting name, quite fitting indeed. This will help align our green money vision as well as create new opportunities in the climate markets. In short, we believe Monetalis can help position Maker as one of the forefronts of the ESG movements. We believe the proper due diligence has been done and are interested in seeing more vome out of this. Ratification Poll for L2-to-L1 Fast Withdrawals (MIP69) - May 9, 2022 We voted YES: With the new Maker teleport, this is a pretty simple and ecstatic yes. We can quickly withdraw DAI first from Eth mainnet to and from L2, Arbitrum and Optimism. When doing so, DAI is minted on one end and destroyed on the other, causing near instant bridges. We are in support of the 1 bps fee as proposed in the signal request as it is much easier to go down in fees than raise them later and could provide another possibly uncorrelated revenue stream for Maker! Ratification Poll for MIP40 Budget Process Amendment (MIP4c2-SP19) - May 9, 2022 We voted YES: It seems rather apparent in our time as delegates that the budget proposal and requests feature is a bit chaotic. We believe this amendment that would help increase the structure of such proposals is something much needed going into the future. Overall we will still rely on the Core Units to make well informed decisions about the budget, but this is a good step forward in standardizing the process. Ratification Poll for Strategic Happiness (SH-001) Core Unit Budget Modification (MIP40c3-SP67) - May 9, 2022 We voted YES: This one man team is quite impressive indeed. We believe that someone who has gone above and beyond to lighten the mood and spread merch amongst the community should be well treated. With not just this Core Unit, but with all, we urge them to be as mindful of the markets and plan their budgets accordingly during these tumultuous times. Overall, we at Penn Blockchain greatly realize the efforts put forth by this cu and are confident it will be kept up! (PS: We would like a few pieces of merch as well haha).

Raise the ESM Minimum Threshold - May 16, 2022 We voted YES: This request that increases the Emergency Shutdown Model from 100,000 MKR to 150,000 MKR is something that should be down immediately, As more and more places, many decentralized, accumulate more and more MKR, at much lower prices, the ability to maliciously shutdown the protocol has decreased over time. This will raise the barrier in dollar terms back to something comparable when it was last agreed upon. Adjust the lid Parameter on the Rate Limited Flapper - May 16, 2022 We voted YES: This change of the lid parameter has no real technical risk. When the burning mechanism does possibly come back into the picture, it limits the maximum number of MKR from 7.2m to 1.4m dai a day; smoothing out the mechanism.

content.content: EXECUTIVE VOTE: Foundational L2 Work, Authorize New Flash Mint Module, MKR Vesting - May 18, 2022 We voted YES: At its core, this executive supports foundation work that needs to be done and is a great step in the right direction. The new flash mint module being updated and newly rolled out is crucial after the manipulation was discovered. And finally, fully support the MKR vesting for the new SES core unit.

Investigate Implementation of an Antalpha Institutional Vault - May 23, 2022 We voted YES: We believe this specific institutional vault should be a high priority for Maker. When digging into the forum post, we see resounding yes support for this vault, from many of the key workers at Maker. Investigate Deploying the MakerDAO Balance Sheet in ETH - May 23, 2022 We voted YES: This is a very important decision for Maker and something that could heavily impact the protocol. As laid out in the original forum post by Seb, by not deploying in Maker, this puts us at a disadvantage to positive price action compared to Tribe, angle, etc. Additionally, with the merge incoming, yields for eth will be quite high making it a productive asset and we can also capture some of that demand now. Contrarily, we advise that at least one year of runway for the protocol should be kept at least in DAI, with initial recommendation of 10% before scaling up or down depending on price action. Launch Maker Teleport with 1 Basis Point Fee - May 23, 2022 We voted YES: A resounding yes. As one of our club members helped out on this proposal, our answer may be a bit biased. However overall as a club, we believe instituting a bridge with a small fee and then deciding to take away or increase is much easier than starting off with no fee and then going up. All the major bridges take a fee of some sort and it could be a great way to provide some passive income for Maker that wouldn’t be as correlated as everything else. Community Greenlight Poll - FEI (Fei USD) - May 16, 2022 We voted YES: This was a rather heavily debated topic in our club. On one hand, FEI has shown resilience during these tumultuous times and held high. However, as said, it is tumultuous times and it’s important to shelter up with safer assets. An important factor in our decision for this came down to our delegate platforms’ value which include factoring into our delegate base, which is overwhelmingly in support. Overall we think the team should have the greenlight in allowing this, but exercise precaution and their expertise in setting parameters and a launch date/time.

EXECUTIVE VOTE: Raise the ESM Minimum Threshold, MKR Vesting, Adjust the lid Parameter on the Rate-limited Flapper - May 25, 2022 We voted YES: Raising the ESM minimum threshold from 100k to 150k is crucial as a malicious attack can be accomplished much easier now at a lower MKR price. Further, the specified MKR for the core units should be sent out to the respective teams. Finally, the lid parameter (which sets the total value of DAI allowed to be sent out to the surplus auctions at once) goes down from 150k to 30k, effectively cutting down the number of parallel flap auctions from 5 to 1.

We hope this is a smooth process and thanks the cus for their hard work. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - May 30, 2022 We voted YES: Looking at the forum discussion by Monet, we agree wholeheartedly with most things said. We believe the debt ceiling adjustments are necessary in this ever changing market and also think increasing the steth debt is a good decision to encourage steth utilization more and more. Short Ratification Poll for MIP10c7-SP2 - Modify Oracle Data Models - May 30, 2022 We voted YES: We are in support of MIP10c7-SP2 being accepted and implemented. The updated oracle data models for the listed paris in the discussion will provide up to date pricing models and is essential for Maker’s health. The pairs listed in the most recent discussion thread are a good addition in our opinion. Short Ratification Poll for MIP10c19-SP1 - Update Oracle Expiration Time for All Oracles - May 30, 2022 We voted YES: This seems like a no brainer. With basically no downside, instead of 15,500 seconds, and using 24 hours instead; if there’s the ability to save from the super high oracle prices, then we might as well use this new timing instead! Looking at the discussion by Mik, it seems like this is an easy move to make.

EXECUTIVE VOTE: Parameter Changes, Starknet Bridge Limit and Authority Changes, Recognized Delegate Compensation, SH-001 Budget Distribution - June 08, 2022 We voted YES: Parameter changes as proposed should be implemented asap. Good to hear debt ceilings for some vaults are set now to 0 as the first step in offboarding. Good to execute Starknet DAI bridge as determined. Good to move forward with the SH cu budget.

Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: We are in huge support of initiatives like these as believe it is important to expanding the utilization and adoption of DAI. As Rema highlighted in her discussion post, many of these things we believe will work towards a higher MKR price price and more liquidity/positive outlook on the token. Management of Velodrome Airdrop and veNFT - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: For anyone remotely familiar with Solidly mechanics, this is pretty much a guaranteed yes for this optimized fork on Optimism. We might want to explore bribes in the future as well. Add rETH as a new Vault Type - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: This was semi tricky, but at the end of the day, we distinguished between FUD and facts, which are Rocket Pool is one of the most trust liquid staking platforms out there, have the upmost security, and are in our opinion, equivalent in nature to that os Lido’s stETH. Although there has been some huge short term FUD, we believe the liquidity is sufficient to warrant a vault with this collateral and that liquidators can properly clear the debt if depegs were to arise. Community Greenlight Poll - KREDIKA (Kredika LTD) - June 6, 2022 We voted NO: Opportunity Cost, Opportunity Cost, Opportunity Cost. A simple discussion with the RWA team shows that they are already close to being at full capacity and to be frank, are working on much more important things. Something we’ve recently been enlightened and realized about is that a lot of these RWA greenlights are just non-practical. Even if they go through, the team still has to spend precious hours explaining why they won’t be able to move forward with such. Community Greenlight Poll - XSGD (StraitsX) - June 6, 2022 We voted NO: See reason above, Opportunity Cost, Opportunity Cost, Opportunity Cost.

Ratification Poll for Adding a Special Purpose Fund - Makershire Hathaway (MIP55c3-SP4) - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: As inflation continues to stay at its current 8%+ we need to find a way to utilize part of our maker treasury so that it doesn’t just continue to waste away. This fund proposal culminates months of hard work and ideation and promises continued attention in the months to come.This fund will increase MKR/DAi utilization, create passive yields, and does NOT decrease the surplus buffer, as all funds are still considered part of it. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Strategic Finance Core Unit Budget, SF-001 (MIP40c3-SP69) - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: The SF core unit has done an amazing job so far in the months they have been active. Not only within the cu, but throughout the community, Mark, Seb, Adrian, and Dan are active in just about any important discussion. It would be a shame to see them leave and find other things to do if they aren’t fairly compensated for their time and visions as it’s obvious they definitely could. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Growth Core Unit Budget, GRO-001 (MIP40c3-SP70) - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: Much like the reasoning for SF cu budget increase, we think the Growth team has done a very good job and especially in times like now, growth is something we need to focus even more on. Ratification Poll for Onboard/Amend Keep3r Network (MIP63c4-SP4) - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: Cheaper costs for the same/ possibly better service; yes all the way! Ratification Poll for Facilitator Onboarding to IS-001 - Psychonaut (MIP41c4-SP34) - June 13, 2022 We voted ABSTAIN: We’ve seen Psychonaut actively post and be in discussions n the forums, but given the alarming messages from people who know him better, we believe we can not appropriately form an important opinion regarding Josh at this time. Ratification Poll for Facilitator Onboarding to DIN-001 - Tadeo (MIP41c4-SP35) - June 13, 2022 We voted ABSTAIN: In similar regards as prior vote, we just have not interacted with Tadeo enough to form a concrete and opinionated decision on this promotion.

content.content: Could you provide some insight into the technical side of your operation? You have over 50 members. Who controls the voting wallet? If it’s a multisig, how does it work? If a signatory graduates/leaves the club, what happens? If a new person joins, what’s the procedure? Apart from participation in offchain debates and votes.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Hey pvl! Thanks for reaching out, would love to provide some insight. Yes, we are well over 50 members, across quite a few different arms. Our club controls a couple different wallets. We have a treasury multisig that’s controlled by four members: three co-presidents (2 undergrad, one grad), and one treasurer. The voting wallet is a separate wallet that contains some gas to vote, and controls the delegations for our different projects. If a signatory graduates/leaves the club, we offboard them from the multisig. If a new person joins the multisig, we add them. It’s rather simple, and the decision is made by the board at the current time.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Juanbug:  does NOT decrease the surplus buffer, as all funds are still considered part of it.   How exactly does this work? If it’s not in the buffer then it can’t offset bad debt. Or do you just mean it’s still an asset?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Pretty much, the value of the funds will add to the surplus buffer, and will be transferred back if need be. Check out last week maker community call! The team gave a 10 minute rundown of Makershire that was helpful for us!

Juanbug:  Pretty much, the value of the funds will add to the surplus buffer, and will be transferred back if need be.   I’m pretty sure that’s technically incorrect. The funds could be transferred back, yes. But they would not be in the surplus buffer. Just like DAI sitting in a CU wallet is not in the surplus buffer but could (in theory) be transferred back

content.content: Hey Ippy, definitely check out the recording from last Thursday regarding the semantics and technicalities, but I guess fundamentally, funds can be returned anytime to surplus buffer on a community vote.

Temporarily Disable the Aave DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) - June 15, 2022 We voted NO: This is the first time we’re opposing an executive vote, however, we have technically voted yes as that is the only option. Here’s our reasoning:   We voted no because it looks like the reflective Aave proposal is not going to pass, the likelihood of an illiquid or underwater DAI liquidity on Aave seems super low. We’re confident in Aave liquidators to appropriately eliminate bad debt if stETH falls even lower on the peg. Even more so in a bear market, this revenue stream is incredibly important and something we don’t think we should turn off currently.   There is no way to no to executive proposals, and so we had to choose to either submit the vote or not. Given the proposal had already passed, and after some talk with Gov Alpha, we ultimately chose in favor of “securing the hat” and following the precedent set by Frank: Flip Flop Flap Delegate LLC Platform - #81 by ElProgreso by still voting on this executive.

Ratification Poll for Adding Lending Oversight Core Unit (LOVE-001) - June 13, 2022 We voted ABSTAIN: Our general reason for voting Abstain in this instance was thinking this core unit might do a lot of the stuff the risk core unit currently does. It seems like there’s a lot of initiatives to cut down right now on budget and this doesn/t seem the most optimal right now. Ratification Poll for Task Forces (MIP75) - June 13, 2022. We voted YES: In general, we’re in favor of initiatives to increase efficiency and this does a pretty good job at doing so in our opinion. A lot of decisions we agree to take too long and having a designated “task force” to carry some of these out is quite important. Ratification Poll for Onboard Growth Task Force (MIP75c3-SP1) - June 13, 2022 We voted Approve Task Force and associated delegated authority to spend funds: Reasoning was similar to above. If we’re approving task force as a core unit to make executive decisions, we don’t see the reason to not vote yes for this. Ratification Poll for MIP16 Amendments (MIP4c2-SP20) - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: Unanimous administrative vote. Ratification Poll for Permissionless Open Market Operations (MIP74) - June 13, 2022 We voted YES: There was some contention around this. Overall, the tech behind allowing this to pass is super important and something we believe we should have in the future. That being said, we don’t think buybacks should happen currently, but see the importance of having the ability to do so in the future.

The surplus buffer is technically just the accounting difference between the assets (incl. retained earnings  from accumulated interest) and the liabilities (outstanding DAI). We apply a broader conceptualization of the surplus buffer to try and make all CU funds junior to equity holders in the event of a loss, in the event of the CU wallet reserves. In this instance, Makershire would be a subset of equity holder funds, technically drawn from the surplus buffer but not in use to fund operating expense budgets. We apply the same framework to our treasury assets. All of this is just an informal assumption (no governance precedent to absorb losses with ENS for eg) but a reasonable approximation to make.  image2492×1702 315 KB

content.content: I’ll circle back but in general meetings, we think decentralization is a great tool for getting mass adoption and onboarding, but a lot of core decisions that could benefit a protocol heavily should have those who are best to make decisions do most of the grunt work before a full community vote. As for redundancy, not sure if you’re asking if we think this is redundant or not, but in general, yeah redundancy = bad haha.

Thank you for the background behind your vote guys. I just wanted to share here as well that overlap between LOVE and RISK is probably at 20% max. While RISK is focused to liquidity and technical issues related to managing vaults and collateral in general, LOVE augments this by overseeing all aspects of structured finance exposure. Those include, among others:  Structures and credit enhancing mechanism (think of a securitisation for example) Process and interest alignment Counterparty and market expertise Internal processes and conflicts of interest  In doing so, LOVE wants to augment RISK deep skills and act as a super streamlined yet senior risk overlay. That is why we intend to attract very few people with 10-15 of experience in banking and financial services. I hope that you’ll reassess the possibility to vote in favour of LOVE if by the end of the voting period your vote will become important in deciding the future of this core unit. Thanks for your engagement, Luca

PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - August 1, 2022 We voted YES: The MOMC proposal here makes sense to us. Specifically, decreasing the WSTETH-B stability fee to 0 to incentivize dai creation while increasing the fee for Uni-lps since they’ve reached highs once again and we might as well earn some yields off of them. Maker Teleport Deployment on Starknet and Associated Risk Parameters - August 1, 2022 We voted YES: Agree with starknet facilitator’s opinions; and are looking forward to this implementation. Tactical Re-allocation Process for Budget Adjustments - August 1, 2022 We voted YES: In general tactical reallocation of the budget for different CUs is needed and we think should be done periodically. Will be very interested to see how discussions go forward. A concern we did have was that the wording on the formal poll was a bit “intense” and seemed to give SFCU a lot more oversight than what the forum signal request emphasized. After confirming that nothing had changed between moving the signal poll onchain, and this new strong wording was just semantics, we saw no reason as to why this shouldn’t “be greenlighted” as it is purely a way to get the ball rolling and won’t make “changes in isolation,”  but instead lead to future proposals after further communication and research. MIP9 Community Greenlight Poll - Pando (Pando Investment Grade Climate Assets) - August 1, 2022 We voted NO: Ultimately our decision can be summarized into: we don’t think the gained extrinsic benefits from taking on this deal in the form of positive publicity offsets the subpar yield for a BBB+ loan, and longer liquidity. We enjoyed reading input from the RWF team, Seb, Delegates, Rune, dbkcan, Blocktower, etc., and were impressed by the level of professionalism and diligence the Pando team took in responding to most major points of concern. Overall, we’re not happy voting no as just the publicity from being able to use DAI as collateral to pay off clean money would be a pretty big step forward in showcasing how blockchain and defi can have tangible real life benefits. Unfortunately, with everything RWA analyzes, there’s a huge opportunity cost. The term maturity of 12 years and WAL of 6 years mean if something goes south, a good chunk of collateral will be closely locked up. Finally, the low ~3% yield on a BBB+ is vastly outperformed by certain A loans earning over 5%. As Jack from Blocktower states well,”it is tough to justify this [2%] gap when the most senior piece of solar securitizations, which has more downside protection, yields 5%.”

content.content: Budget Ratification Poll for Modify TechOps Core Unit DAI Budget, TECH-001 (MIP40c3-SP86) - November 14, 2022 We voted Reject Budget: First off, if I’m reading the SES Expense board (here) correctly, Tech Ops spent $63,000 on travel and entertainment in September?! This seems very steep, especially for market conditions at that time. Looking at their last four month reported expenses:  June: $86,756.97 July: $85,209.39 August: $165,261.75 (compensation increased from 65k to 130k+, more than doubled from prior months. Curious what this was?) September: $113,358.99 (taking out the $63,000 of travel and entertainment when considering budget renewal) October & November: No data  Adding up these four months gets $450,587.10. Pro-rated to 1 year gets $1.35mil. We believe this should be the bear case, (call it 1.5mil or so). This was a tough decision as we understand techops has a lot on their plate and will have a lot in the upcoming year, however, the 2.4mil they requested, which is a 75%+ increase over what we think is fair in current market conditions, is just too high. We’d love to see a reproposal with a modified bear and base case, as many other proposals have done. PS: Would love some clarity from the core team, or anyone who knows, about rather peculiar spending reporting.

Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Mandate (MIP39c2-SP38) - November 14, 2022 & Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security (IS-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP83) - November 14, 2022 We voted NO & Reject Budget: Looking at many of these budget renewals in an endgame focused 2023, they don’t work as well as last year. We think many parts of the updated mandate would work well if Endgame wasn’t “around” but current goals to move towards ecosystem actors are what IS should become in the future, hence our no votes for both. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Governance Communications Core Unit DAI Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP84) - November 14, 2022 We voted Reject Budget: In line with our IS decision, we think the TechOps team should gradually move to Ecosystem Actors. Overall, we like Flipside crypto idea of combining with Gov Alpha, and this could consolidate and output concise info regarding communications for Endgame in the upcoming months. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit DAI Budget, SAS-001 (MIP40c3-SP85) - November 14, 2022 We voted Reject Budget: This falls in line with our IS/Gov Comm decisions. We believe that SAS would be better suited as an EA. We’re super thankful for much of the work that pioneered volatile asset types last year, but from a new development standpoint, we’re in favor of them being their independent service provider versus the hefty budget renewal. Ratification Poll for Modify Emulated Surplus Buffer Upper Limit (MIP84c10-SP1) - November 14, 2022 We voted NO: We’re looking forward to the launch of POVE and think the current upper limit is a good limit. Don’t think the modified limits are necessary/beneficial currently. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify the Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit DAI Budget, SES-001 (MIP40c3-SP87) - November 14, 2022 We voted Approve speedy operations platform option budget: First of all, the SES team has been comparatively using up and needing most of the budget for their request more. For many of these renewals, we see teams utilizing 50% of their requested budgets from last year, meaning their bear case budgets are still like 25%+ of what they currently spend; therefore in reality, no real decreased costs and budget cuts are happening. This is not the case for SES, and we believe the slightly increased request for speedily getting Endgame up and running this upcoming year is necessary and well deserved before they wind down operations/ become EAs.

Hi @Juanbug ! Nice to e-meet you  Really appreciate the reasoning for your vote, apologies we missed it. I’ll try and cover your raised points one by one: Travel expenses draw - a lump sum had to be drawn to be able to book all the travel related expenses - hotel, flights, co-working space and any activities. That is the technical reason, on a more human level, this expense is essential to the team morale because of the fact that the whole team never actually met each other face to face! It is crucial for the team to get together in one place, spend some time together, plan for the future and simply get to know each other. We’ve never done this (not in 2021 or 2022) and will be aiming for 2 of these “off-sites” next year (2023). Lastly whatever is not spent from that 63k of course will be returned. Compensation increase in August - 2 (fantastic) new hires. It was mentioned in Core Unit updates forum thread. Expenses data in the Dashboard - this is uploaded on the monthly basis around mid month for the previous month. So October data is up, November will come max mid December if not earlier. In addition we are also using GitHub to publish expense reports. As a general comment on the budget amount - remember the number requested is an absolute max cap. So looking at this years budget and expenses, we’ve under spent over 1 mil from this year… Yes we should probably tighten up our forecast in the future but in this dynamic infrastructure world and the crazy crypto tech space we’re in we opted to be on the safe side. Let us know if that clears it up a bit. Simon and Dumitru!
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely positive feedback on proposal

content.content: Hey team! Thanks so much for your response. Thanks for the team/expense updates. As for the actual budget, I think starting off it’s important to understand and praise the CU for all the work they do, maker couldn’t run without you guys. As for the budget request, I understand you underspent by over a mil, and appreciate the clarity on that front. Are there intentions to return overused funds?/draw upon only funds needed. This is more of a question of I think it’s more fair and almost expected in current times to try and be frugal/draw upon only funds needed. Nonetheless, thanks for the explanation.

Adjust the GUSD PSM Debt Ceiling - January 16, 2023 & Decrease GUSD PSM Fee Out (tout) - January 16, 2023 We voted NO CHANGE & NO: This was a very in depth and thorough vote for us. We talked with many different sides including the Gemini team themselves. Overall, we decided and think that the news with Genesis DOES NOT impact the core operations of GUSD and Gemini. Given all the discussion on the forums and the core Gemini team’s reassurances, we are confident enough that 1) The Gemini team will not be liable for this ~900m hole that Genesis frauded Gemini’s customers on and 2) In an esoteric situation where Gemini core product goes under, GUSD will still be fully redeemable and with high liquidity due to its US (New York) oversight and history/set up. Further, the current deal we have with Gemini is one of the best proposals in the space for MakerDAO and considering the very sizable $500k December payment, a $6m yearly revenue if very important to the DAO and something that we believe the benefits heavily outweigh the benefits for. Therefore, we are in favor of maximizing GUSD in the PSM as before, hence the above votes.

Ratification Poll for Amend MIP51 to Remove MIP51c4 (Calendar Exceptions) (MIP4c2-SP28) - January 9, 2023 We voted NO: Given the location of a large majority of the DAO, it seems that most people are in demographics where December is filled with many holidays. content.content: EXECUTIVE VOTE: Emergency Parameter Changes - March 11, 2023 We voted YES: Voting to have these emergency parameters set in place. This weekend was an unprecedented USDC fear balloon and is the first time we’ve seen such fallout with USDC. Looking back, while rejoiced everything worked out well, this goes to show the importance of a few key features like a PSM 2.0 being introduced in a timely manner. EXECUTIVE VOTE: Return Excess MIP65 Funds to Surplus Buffer - March 13, 2023 We voted YES: Looking forward to seeing dividends be paid back to the DAO/SB! Stoked to see the USDC earning yields passively. Short Ratification Poll for Vault Setting Amendment Subproposal (MIP92c5-SP1) - March 13, 2023 We voted NO: Would be very interested to see this revisited in the future, however, just due to how so much “drama” happened, this proposal got lost under the radar and we believe adequate discussion around it has not happened.

EXECUTIVE VOTE Emergency PSM Changes - March 14, 2023 We voted YES: Voting yes to these emergency changes such that in case an adverse scenario like last weekend were to actually happen, we can be better prepared to defend the peg and not have a spiral disastrous effect. Thanks to Risk and PE teams for all their work this week.
